section.title: Overall architecture
section.para: The architecture of the ADL frontend is inspired by FractalADL. The main role of the ADL frontend is to parse ADL input files, check them and build an Abstract Syntax Tree (aka. AST). The frontend is organized as a chain of delegating loader components. Each loader is responsible for the verification and the enhancement for a dedicated aspect of the language (checking of bindings, template instantiation, resolution of extended definitions, ...). A loader component may use a sub-chain for the resolution of complex tasks in which multiple language aspects are involved (resolution of definition references for instance).

The following schema presents the high-level architecture of the ADL front-end. In this figure, the direction of the arrow corresponds to the direction of the invocation. That is, the component which is at the source of the arrows calls the component which is at the target of the arrow to delegate the processing operation.

As depicted in the Figure, the leaf node of the loader delegation chain is the ADL parser component. This is the one which parses an ADL files and returns an initial AST that contains all the information which is captured in the ADL file. This AST is taken by the Loader Chain component, which is composed of many sub-components. For instance, one of these sub-components loads tha IDL files which are referenced in the ADL files. This sub-component uses the IDL Loader sub-chain. Another component of the Loader Chain resolved the references to other ADL files (e.g. the definition of the sub-components which are used in the input ADL file). Such a component would use the Definition Resolver Sub-Chain. Note that, the latter delegates the processing to the ADL Loader. That is, when an ADL definition refers to another one, the processing is forked to load the refered definitin before finishing the processing of the initial ADL definition. This way, the loading process of an ADL definition is done recursively, with the depth-first strategy.

Another important component in the Loader Chain is the ADL Cache component. The latter is used to store the definitions which are loaded once in order to return them without reloading them, for optimization purposes.

section.title: ADL AST structure
section.para: The AST of the ADL is structured as a graph of nodes. Each node has a set of attributes and a set of container interfaces to give access to other nodes which are related to it. The set of attributes that can be accessed through a node depends on the type of the node. Each node type captures a different elements of the ADL language. See for details on the FractalADL AST framework, which constitutes the basis of the &productName;.

section.title: Structure of the ADL AST
section.para: The following schema gives an overview of the AST:

As depicted in this Figure, the root node of the AST that corresponds to and ADL file is a . The MindDefinition class extends the generic interface from FractalADL. It has a name and may contains a set of referenced definitions corresponding to the definition this ADL extends.

A MindDefinition node may be representing a Type, Primitive or Composite definition. Depending on the kind of definitio which is represented, the MindDefinition implements a different set of container interfaces. For instance, a node that represents a Primitive definition implements the InterfaceContainer, AttrobuteContainer and ImplementationContainer interfaces whereas the Composite definitin implements the InterfaceContainer, ComponentContainer and BindingContainer interfaces.
The nodes such as the Interface or the Binding have only some attributes to give access to the information which is captured for these basic elements.

The Component nodes represent the sub-components of a composite component. It gives direct access to the instance name of the sub-component that it represents. Furthermore, it also gives access to a DefinitionReference node. The latter is used as a bridge to bind the sub-component to its definition. The DefinitionReference node contains the name of the definitoins which is refered to. It also gives access to the MindDefinitoin representing the definition of the sub-component through the DefinitionReferenceContainer interface. Note that, multiple component instances belonging to the same type refer to the same MindDefinition node representing their definition.

section.para: The definition reference resolved sub-chain is responsible to find the corresponding to a given .

The last component in the definition reference resolver delegation chain is the . This component simply uses the main loader chain to retrieve the ADL definition whose name corresponds to the name contained in the definition reference. Other components in the chain are responsible to check that the definition reference is correct regarding the actual definition. In particular the component checks that the arguments contained by the definition reference matches formal parameters declared by the definition.

Similarly, the component checks values given to formal type parameters of a generic definition. Moreover this component delegates the creation of a unique template instance to the template instantiation sub-chain (see for more details concerning template instantiation).
The handles definition references that contains both type arguments and arguments. For instance this component transforms D1<P1(10, 11), P2("foo")> to D1<P1, P2>(10, 11, "foo").
The scans import statements to transform the simple name contained in the definition reference into a fully-qualified name.

Finally the stores the resolved definition corresponding to given definition reference into an AST decoration attached to the definition reference. This avoid to re-execute the whole definition reference resolver sub-chain for the same definition reference.

section.para: The anonymous definition extraction sub-chain is responsible to extract anonymous definition contained by component nodes and transforms it in fully formed definition. section.title: Error reporting in the ADL frontend
section.para:
When an error is detected in the ADL frontend, it is reported to the
service (see ). When a definition reference cannot be resolved to an existing definition, the component logs the error and return an unresolved definition AST node. Loader components can test if a definition is an unresolved definition AST node using the isUnresolvedDefinitionNode method of the class.

section.title: Serialization of AST and incremental ADL loading
section.para: To improve toolchain performances, the component tries to load ADL definitions from files containing a serialization of the AST that have been produced by a previous execution of the toolchain. If the binary file is found, the BynaryADLLoader deserializes the AST and checks if it is up-to-date by checking the timestamps of all the input resources (see ) attached to the AST.

section.title: Support for annotations in ADL
section.para:
Annotations founds in ADL files are checked and resolved to an object by the
service (see ). Annotation processors classes can be associated to annotations. An annotation processor class that must be executed during the ADL loading must implements the interface. Annotation processors can be executed at different phases of the ADL Loading. For each of these phases, the ADL loader chain contains, at a different place, an component.
